This shell and core EPC was produced to enable the sale or rent of the property. It was set up with notional fixed services based on the unit’s use class. The activity within the building was specified in line with business activity typical of the use class, and the most energy intensive fit-out adopted in line with Part L of the Building Regulations in force when the building was refurbished. The incoming tenant should seek to specify an energy efficient fit out complying with Part L of the Building Regulations with potential enhancements.

In accordance with EPC Conventions then the benchmark efficiency data has been used based upon assumptions of the systems age. Improvements to the EPC score are likely to be achieved by allowing assessors access to the HVAC equipment and associated commissioning data. It is recommended that any future surveys be permitted access to the plant and data to allow a more accurate EPC score in line with the prevailing EPC Conventions.

Installation data for the most recent lighting installation was not made available. It has therefore been necessary to assign lighting by type in accordance with the EPC Conventions. It is recommended that for good practice, all relevant design documentation be kept and maintained on-site or made available to assessors to allow for more accurate EPC results.
Replace the remaining PL type fittings with modern LED alternatives.
Consider replacing T8 lamps with retrofit T5 conversion kit.

Raise the air conditioning set-point temperatures to 24degC for summer cooling and reduce to 20degC for winter heating. Around 4% saving can be made on running costs for every 1K the temperature is increased during cooling periods. Install guidance notices adjacent to remote controls to advise of recommended control settings.
Consider replacing CFL lamps and T8/T5 fluorescent fittings with LED equivalents where not already fitted. Payback period will depend on hours of use, technology utilised and cost.

Air conditioning controller in server room was set to 20degC which is below recommended limits. New guidance from ASHRAE (American Society Heating Refrigeration and Air Conditioning Engineers) recommends that data centre/comms rooms etc. temperatures can be increased to between 24degC and 27degC depending upon the age of the installed equipment. It is recommended that the client raises the set-points in small increments of 0.5K and monitors the performance of the servers/communication equipment. As these systems operate 24/7 any increase in set-point will lead to a substantial annual saving.

Most areas that require PIRs have been fitted with them, but some tea rooms and toilets have not had them fitted and lights where found on when rooms were empty. Consider fitting PIR movement/daylight sensors in these areas.

Several of the air conditioning units on site are still charged with R22 refrigerant and are non-inverter controlled; as of January 2015 no remedial maintenance can be carried which requires the use of recycled or reclaimed HCFC refrigerants. This AC equipment should be considered
Fit pipe insulation and insulated jackets to exposed distribution valves and pipes within boiler/hot water plant room areas, to reduce distribution heat losses within the HVAC system.
Investigate building construction and consider improving insulation to walls, floors and roofs to latest Building Regulations.

Most of the single glazed windows on site are already fitted with retro fitted secondary glazing. Consider fitting secondary glazing where missing or consider replacing all single glazed windows with modern conservation approved multi glazed equivalents to latest Building Regulations.

A default lighting efficacy of 60 lamp lumens per circuit Watt has been assumed for the A3 retail unit as this will be installed later by a future tenant, Manual controls only have also been assumed. It is recommended that high efficiency LED lighting with PIR occupancy and daylight dimming controls are selected and installed as part of the fit-out.

A default VRF cooling efficiency of 2.6 has been assumed for the A3 retail unit as this is likely to be installed later by a future tenant, It is recommended that a higher efficiency system is installed as part of the fit-out.

A default VRF heating efficiency of 2.6 has been assumed for the A3 retail unit as this is likely to be installed later by a future tenant, It is recommended that a higher efficiency system is installed as part of the fit-out.

As the kitchen extract fan for the A3 retail unit will be provided by a future tenant, the default value of 1W/l.s has been used. It is recommended that an extract fan with a greater efficiency is installed by the tenant.

Some default HVAC efficiencies have had to be used to create this EPC as they could not be supplied by the building owner facilities team, creating a up to date building management manual which include building (HVAC) plant efficiency figures,  such as EER, SEER, SCOP, COP, Supply and Extract AHUs Specific Fan Powers (W/l-s) and air flow rates (l/s/m2) and relevant CHP data would help in many areas of energy efficiency analysis and building facilities improvement projects.
Consider installing hard-wired 7 day timers to newly installed hot water heaters in newly refurbished areas, to reduce energy consumption out of operating hours.

Consider replacing few remaining T8 fittings and when next reviewing lighting consider replacing  CFL lamps & T5 fittings with LED equivalents where not already fitted. Also consider installing lamps with integrated daylight/sensor controls. Payback period will depend on hours of use, technology utilised and cost.

Consider fitting PIR movement/daylight sensors to lighting in toilets, corridors, store rooms, tea rooms, offices and any other low occupancy areas to help reduce energy consumption when rooms are unoccupied but lights are left on and not already fitted. Payback period will depend on hours of use, technology utilised and cost.

When using air conditioning, consider raising the air conditioning set-point temperatures to 24°C for summer cooling and reduce to 20°C for winter heating. Around 4% saving can be made on running costs for every 1K the temperature is increased during cooling periods. Install guidance notices adjacent to remote controls to advise of recommended control settings.

Consider fitting PIR movement/daylight sensors to lighting in tea room, offices , corridors and other low occupancy areas  to help reduce energy consumption when rooms are unoccupied but lights are left on. Payback period will depend on hours of use, technology utilised and cost.
Consider replacing CFL lamps & T8/T5 PL fittings with LED equivalents where not already fitted. Payback period will depend on hours of use, technology utilised and cost.

Consider adding valve insulation jackets to exposed heating distribution valves within the plant room area where not already fitted, to reduce heat loss through the distribution pipework and reduce boiler operation.

The site roof could be a good location for Solar Photovoltaics (PV), with the introduction of Feed-in Tariffs (FiTs) the payback period for this technology has been reduced making it an attractive environmental solution for commercial buildings.
Consider replacing single glazed windows with modern multi glazed equivalents to latest Building Regulations, where not already fitted.
Investigate building construction and consider improving insulation to walls, floors and roof to latest Building Regulations.

Building staff stated that new boilers where in the process of being installed this will only have a positive effect on the EPC rating. When next reviewing hot water boiler consider installing with solar thermal assist technologies.
